Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Slow and Stopped Light Photonics with Atomic Spectroscopy Chips

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to create the first set of quantum interference based slow and stopped light photonic devices. Quantum interference creates some of the strongest light-matter interactions ever observed, including electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT), slow light, and stopped light. A large number of possible applications exist, including optical data processing, enhanced sensing, (quantum) optical memories, and quantum information processing. However, to date there is no viable platform that combines large quantum interference effects with photonic device integration.
The intellectual merit of this project is to explore the use of a recently developed self-contained atomic spectroscopy platform for creating a new class of photonic devices based on quantum interference. To this end, a second generation hollow-core waveguide spectroscopy chip for high temperature and high optical density operation will be developed and used to demonstrate stopped light on a chip. A set of novel, canonical photonic devices for chip-scale sensing and optical signal processing based on quantum interference, slow and stopped light will be demonstrated. This new class of devices will have transformative impact on the use of non-solid (atomic) media for photonics.
The broader impacts of this work are to unite several fields, including microfabrication, integrated optics, atomic spectroscopy, and device physics. This collaborative project will provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to acquire a unique, multidisciplinary skill set. The program is complemented by a number of outreach efforts to recruit undergraduate students from underrepresented groups through established and successful programs at UCSC and BYU, respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project were to further the development of atomic spectroscopy chips for atomic vapor spectroscopy suitable for implementing slow and stopped light on a chip. Optical quantum interference effects are known to modify the propagation speed of a light pulse in an atomic medium which has a broad range of applications in metrology and communications to name but a few.

Intellectual merit: Over the course of this project, we devised a new set of integrated photonic devices that allow for using stopped light in a new context, i.e. to create photonic devices such as pulse multiplexers. Moreover, we devised a new way for using light to slow down atoms. Previous methods relied on dynamically changing the color of the laser source or spatially inhomogeneous magnetic fields. Our approach is conceptually much simpler, relying only on the laser power changing with distance which in turn changes the resonance frequency of the atoms to compensate for the changing Doppler shift as atoms are beginning to slow down. Finally, we developed a novel approach to hollow-core waveguides filled with atomic vapors by using a series of micronscale holes along the length of the waveguide. This approach yielded excellent results in terms of stability and absorption performance and will form the basis of future developments such as on-chip optical quantum memories.

Broader impact: Broader impact of the work was ensured by providing graduate and undergraduate students with a diverse skill set that covers both optical waveguide design, fabrication, and atomic spectroscopy. In addition, graduate student exchange visits between the collaborating universityies were carried out.
